posts.name: EricRehder
posts.cooked:
Anyone know of a compact system for making 90 deg bends in 1/8" 6061 Al?

Our team is up and running with a CNC router making our custom cutouts in polycarb and Al. It would be nice to put a bend into some of them for some mounting configurations. Essentially make a custom bracket like:

There are many nice compact systems out there(Grizzly, Kaka, Shopfox) but limited to ~ 12 gauge bends.

Unfortunately, nothing less than a hydraulic press brake is going to easily bend aluminum that thick at room temperature.

Additionally, 6061, which usually comes with a T6 temper, is very difficult to bend without cracking.

One way that bending can be done is by designing relief holes along the bend line to make it weaker there, then heating the aluminum to anneal it and bend it easier. A common way to do this is to coat the area to be bent in soot from a lighter, then hit it with a torch until the soot vaporizes, putting it just above an annealing temperature but below the melting point. At this point, you can bend it by hand with pliers, but be aware of the aluminum being very hot.

The big drawback with this is because you have to anneal the bend zone, you get a much weaker part along the bend.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
What guage/thickness are you targeting? 12 only or some lighter stuff as well?  How large of flanges (length of bend?)

The $15 option: https://www.menards.com/main/tools/hand-tools/pliers-plier-sets/irwin-reg-vise-grip-reg-sheet-metal-tool-pliers/23/p-1444436136870-c-9156.htm?exp=false

The $70 option: https://www.harborfreight.com/30-inch-bending-brake-67240.html I have bent some pretty thick stuff in this one for short bends, mostly polycarb. Note you will need your own c clamps.

A lot of short bends can be done with a vice, 2 by 4, and a deadblow hammer. (Although they are almost certainly not a strong as done properly)

posts.name: EricRehder
posts.cooked: OK, I found a harbor freight version. Yeah, looks like need a bigger hydraulic and bigger V.

posts.name: EricRehder
posts.cooked: 1/8" thickness Al 8" length of bend should be fine. Trying to avoid these enormous 48" wide machines I see…

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
There are some out there that mount into the jaws of a reasonablely robust vice.

Not the easiest to use, but a middle-ground in size and force.

Make reinforcement channels, ribs and much more all with one convenient, easy to store tool.

Price: USD 95.99

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
gopherguts2:

Additionally, 6061, which usually comes with a T6 temper, is very difficult to bend without cracking.

This is the most important point here.

If you’re planning to bend aluminum, use 5052 (5052-H32 is usually a safe bet)

Second, if you haven’t done sheet metal bending before, definitely make some test bends first and confirm your bend allowance, and that the material you have bends as you expect.  There’s nothing like spending a bunch of time cutting custom parts, only to find out that they don’t fit, or you can’t bend them properly.  This goes double if you’re thinking about doing more than one bend per part – make sure you can actually fit the part into your tool to make those bends.

Even aluminum is anisotropic, to some extent – 5052 usually has a grain direction in which it is more likely to crack if you make zero-radius bends in thick material.

To find your bend allowance , cut a strip of the stock you intend to use, mark three lines along the strip – before bend, bend location, after bend – and measure where they are (or just mark one in the middle and cut the ends square).  Then, bend at the middle mark and evaluate: measure where your marks (or ends) ended up with respect to the bend, the outer radius, the inner radius, the achieved angle, any cracking.  This is also a good way to practice locating bends accurately – if you don’t hit the line properly, both sides of your part will come out incorrectly.

link_counts.title: Guide to Calculating Bend Allowance and Bend Deduction | SendCutSend

posts.name: Sean Lavery
posts.cooked: 1712 also has one of those vice-mounted sheet metal breaks. However, our experience doesn’t quite match that described above, with mediocre-to-poor results when attempting to bend 1/8" aluminum (even 5052). 1/16" bends like a charm, but 1/8" often ends up cracking when we use it.

posts.name: JacobD
posts.cooked: Another trick is to mill slots along the bend radius which will enable you to bend thicker aluminum easier.

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
As others have said, you will need to anneal 6061 before bending it. My preferred method is to mark the bend line with a sharpie and then use a torch to heat along the line until it fades.

If you are using a press brake style punch and die to bend 1/8" aluminum you’ll want to use a V die with at minimum around a 1" opening similar to the vise mounted one linked above.

posts.name: Tom Line
posts.cooked:
You can go a step further, but along the same avenue of the vise break.

Harbor freight hydraulic press + Swag Off Road Finger brakes:

Many of the products offered at Swag Off Road are an industry first. Every product is designed, developed, prototyped and tested here in Oregon & 100% proudly made in the USA.

We specialize in off road products as well as unique & innovative...

You can bend anything you want up to the width of the brake.  This is what we have.  I will say getting a perfect 90 can be a bit of a nuisance - but bending stuff is easy.  Your arm will get tired pumping the bottle jack though =)

Harbor Freight just released a new 12" hydraulic press brake attachment , costing $160. Put it under a 12- to 20-ton hydraulic press, and it’s supposed to be able to bend “mild steel and aluminum up to 12 in. long and 3/8 in. thick”

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
I dissuaded our team from doing what you are considering when I asked them how they were going to ensure that the bends are consistently accurate and they couldn’t figure out a way. It can be done, but it would take a lot of experimentation, practice, and time to get consistently acceptable results.

I guided them to redesign their mechanisms and structures to use 90 degree brackets made from sections of 2" x 2" pre-punched angle from West Coast Products ( WCP -0930). They were pretty easy to cut using our chopsaw or bandsaw and the exact length was not critical to the design.

Access User Guide, Kit Contents

Price: USD 39.99

In the past, we have made 90 degree brackets by cutting sections of 2x1 pre-punched tube.

posts.name: EricRehder
posts.cooked: 100% agree. I’m nervous about that. Easy to put a bend at the wrong location and to put a tilt in it as well. I’m hopeful that we can 3D print a jig to help with this alignment of the piece to the tool.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
EricRehder:

Easy to put a bend at the wrong location and to put a tilt in it as well

That was the point I was trying to make to my students. One would then have to spend time to make everything line up again, if it is even possible.

One of the teams near us just spent over $10k (I think) on a small CNC sheet metal brake so they can make their own bent sheet metal parts to a high quality level. It is essentially an automated version of the brake presses others have been providing links for with a controlled stop for the workpiece. I would imagine that it comes with software to set the workpiece stop at the right place based on parameters such as the material thickness and target bend angle. That’s a big jump up from the solutions that have been discussed in this thread so far that probably cost under $500.
